sp.p: It be lucky vor he I be's zoo pratty behaved, or dom if I—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Who—what?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Nothing at all, where's Henry?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Here, farmer.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Thee woult'nt leave us, Henry, wou't?

sp.speaker: Heny.
sp.p: Leave you! What, leave you now, when by my exertion I can pay off part of the debt of gratitude I owe you? oh, no!

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Nay, it were not vor that I axed, I promise thee; come, gi' us thy hand on't then (shaking hands). Now I'll tell ye. Zur Philip did send vor I, about the money I do owe 'un; and said as how he'd make all strait between us—

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That was kind.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Yes, deadly kind. Make all strait on condition I did turn Henry out o' my doors.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Where will his hatred cease?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And what did you say, Tummas?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Why, I zivelly tould un, if it were agreeable to he to behave like a brute, it were agreeable to I to behave like a man.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That was right. I wou'd have told him a great deal more.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Ah! likely. Then a zaid I shou'd ha a bit of laa vor my pains.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And do you imagine I will see you suffer on my account? No—I will remove this hated form—

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p:
No, but thee shat'un—thee shat'un—I tell thee. Thee have givun me thy hand on't, and dom'me, if thee shat budge one step out of this house. Drabbit it! what can he do? he can't send
us to jail. Why, I have corn will zell for half the money I do owe 'un—and ha'nt I cattle and sheep? deadly lean to be zure—and ha'nt I a thumping zilver watch, almost as big as thy head? and Dame here a got—How many silk gowns have thee got, Dame?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Three, Tummas—and sell them all— and I'll go to church in a stuff one—and let Mrs. Grundy turn up her nose as much as she pleases.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, my friends, my heart is full. Yet a day will come, when this heart will prove its gratitude.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: That day, Henry, is every day.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Dang it! never be down hearted. I do know as well as can be, zome good luck will turn up. All the way I comed whoam I look'd to vind a purse in the path, but I did'nt though.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ah! here they are coming to fell I suppose—

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Lettun—lettun, zeize and zell; we ha gotten here (striking his breast) what we won't zell, and they can't zell. (knocking again) Come in —dang it, don't ye be shy.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah! the strangers I saw this morning. These are not officers of law.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Noa! walk in, Gemmen. Glad to zee ye wi 'all my heart and zoul. Come, Dame, spread a cloth, bring out cold meat, and a mug of beer.
That is the boy.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Take a chair, Zur.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I thank, and admire your hospitality, Don't trouble yourself, good woman.—I am not inclined to eat.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: That be the case here. To-day none o'we be auver hungry: misfortin be apt to stay the stomach confoundely.—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Has misfortune reached this humble dwelling?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Ees, Zur. I do think vor my part it do work its way in every where.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, never despair.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: I never do, Zur. It is not my way. When the sun do shine I never think of voul weather, not I; and when it do begin to rain I always think that's a zure zign it will give auver.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Is that young man your son?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: No, Zur—I do wish he were we all my heart and zoul.
Sir, remember.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Doubt not my prudence. Young man, your appearance interests me;—how can I serve you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: By informing me who are my parents.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: That I cannot do.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Then, by removing from me the hatred of Sir Philip Blandford.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Does Sir Philip hate you?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: With such severity, that even now he is about to ruin these worthy creatures, because they have protected med.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Indeed! misfortune has made him cruel. That should not be.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Noa, it should not indeed, Zur.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It shall not be.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Shan't it, Zur? But how shan't it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I will prevent it.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Wool ye faith and troth? Now, Dame, did not I zay zome good luck would turn up?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, did I hear you rightly? Will you preserve my friends;—will you avert the cruel arm of power, and make the virtuous happy? my tears must thank you

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Young man, you oppress me—forbear! I do not merit thanks—pay your gratitude where you are sure 'tis due—to Heaven. Observe me—here is a bond of Sir Philip Blandford's for £. 1000—do you present it to him, and obtain a discharge for the debt of this worthy man. The rest is at your own disposal— no thanks.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But, Sir, to whom am I thus highly indebted?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My name is Morrington. At present that information must suffice.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Zur, if I may be zo bold—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, friend—

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Don't be angry I had'nt thanked you, Zur, nor I wont.—Only, Zur, I were going to ax when you wou'd call again. You shall have my stampt note vor the money, you shall indeed, Zur. And in the mean time, I do hope you'll take zomeit in way of remembrance as'twere.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Will your Honor put a couple of turkies in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Or pop a ham under your arm? don't ye zay no, if it's agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Farewel, good friends, I shall repeat my visit soon.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: The sooner the better.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Good bye to ye, Zur—Dame and I wool go to work as merry as crickets. Good bye, Henry.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Heaven bless your Honour—and I hope you will carry as much joy away with you, as you leave behind you—I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Young man, proceed to the castle and demand an audience of Sir Philip Blandford. In your way thither I'll instruct you further.—Give me your hand.

div3.stage: Exeunt. MORRINGTON, looking stedfastly on HENRY, GERALD following.]

div3.head: SCENE. II.—An apartment in the castle.
div3.stage: Sir PHILIP BLANDFORD discovered—Miss BLAND FORD reading.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Shall I proceed to the next essay?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What does it treat of?

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Love and friendship.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: A satire?

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: No, father;—an eulogy.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Thus do we find in the imaginations of men, what we in vain look for in their hearts.— Lay it by (a knocking at the door). Come in.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: My dear master, I am a petitioner to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: None possesses a better claim to my favour—ask, and receive.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir. The unhappy Henry.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: What of him—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Emma—go to your apartment.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Poor Henry—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Imprudent man—

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.stage: (Sir PHILIP turns from him with resentment)
sp.p: Nay, be not angry, he is without, and entreats to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I cannot, will not again behold him.

sp.speaker: Ever.
sp.p: I am sorry you refuse me, as it compels me to repeat his words: "If," said he, "Sir Philip denies my humble request, tell him I demand to see him."

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Demand to see me! well, his high command shall be obeyed then (sarcastically); bid him approach.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: By what title, Sir, do you thus intrude on me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: By one of an imperious nature, the title of a creditor.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I your debtor!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes; for you owe me justice. You, perhaps, withhold from me the inestimable treasure of a parent's blessing.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: To the business that brought you hither.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Thus then—I believe this is your signature

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! (recovering himself) it is—

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Affixed to a bond of £. 1000, which by assignment is mine. By virtue of this I discharge the debt of your worthy tenant Ashfield; who, it seems, was guilty of the crime of vindicating the injured and protecting the unfortunate. Now, Sir Philip, the retribution my hate demands is, that what remains of this obligation may not be now paid to me, but wait your entire convenience and leisure.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: No; that must not be.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, why thus oppress an innocent man?—why spurn from you a heart that pants to serve you? No answer, farewell

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hold—one word before we part— tell me—I dread to ask it (aside). How came you possessed of this bond?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: A stranger, whose kind benevolence stept in, and saved—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Fiend! tormentor! has he caught me!—You have seen this Morrington?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Did he speak of me?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
He did—and of your daughter. "Conjure him," said he, "not to sacrifice the lovely Emma by a marriage her heart revolts at." Teil him the life and fortune of a parent are not his own. He holds them but in trust for his offspring.
Bid him reflect, that while his daughter merits the brightest rewards a father can bestow, she is by that father doomed to the harshest fate tyranny can inflict.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Torture (with vehemence). Did he say who caused this sacrifice?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: He told me you had been duped of your fortune by sharpers.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Aye. He knows that well. Young man, mark me—This Morrington, whose precepts wear the face of virtue, and whose practice seems benevolence, was the chief of the hellish banditti that ruined me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: That bond you hold in your hand was obtained by robbery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Not by the thief who, encountering you as a man, stakes life against life, but by that most cowardly villain, who, in the moment when reason sleeps and passion is roused, draws his snares around you, and hugs you to your ruin; then fattening on the spoil, insults the victim he has made.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: On your soul is Morrington that man?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: On my soul he is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Thus, then, I annihilate the detested act—and thus I tread upon a villain's friendship

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Rash boy! What have you done?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: An act of justice to Sir Philip Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: For which you claim my thanks?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p:
Sir, I am thanked already—here (pointing to his heart). Curse on such wealth; compared with its possession, poverty is splendour. Fear not for me—I shall not feel the piercing cold; for in that man whose heart beats warmly for his fellow
low creatures, the blood circulates with freedom— My food shall be what few of the pampered sons of greatness can boast of, the luscious bread of independence; and the opiate that brings me sleep, will be the recollection of the day passed in innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Noble boy! Oh! Blandford!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: What have I faid?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: You called me Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: 'T was error—'T was madness.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Blandford! a thousand hopes and fears rush on my heart. Disclose to me my birth—be it what it may, I am your slave for ever. Refuse me, you create a foe, firm and implacable as—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! am I threatened? Do not extinguish the spark of pity my breast is warmed with.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I will not. Oh, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, on one condition—leave me: Ah! some one approaches. Begone, I insist—I entreat.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: That word has charmed me. I obey, Sir. Philip—you may hate, but you shall respect me.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: At last, thank heaven, I have found somebody. But, Sir Philip, were you indulging in soliloquy—You seem agitated.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, Sir, rather indisposed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Upon my soul, I am devilish glad to find you. Compared with this Castle, the Cretan labyrinth was intelligible; and unless some kind Ariadne gives me a clue, I shant have the pleasure of seeing you above once a week.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, I have been an inattentive host.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Oh, no; but when a house is so devilish large, and the party so very small, they ought to keep together; for to say the truth, tho' no one on earth feels a warmer regard for Robert Handy than I do—I soon get heartily sick of his company—whatever he may be to others, he's a cursed bore to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Where is your worthy father?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: As usual, full of contrivances that are impracticable, and improvements that are retrograde; forming, altogether, a whimsical instance of the confusion of arrangement, the delay of expedition, the incommodiousness of accommodation, and the infernal trouble of endeavouring to save it —he has now a score or two of workmen about him, and intends pulling down some apartments in the east wing of the Castle.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! ruin!—Within there!
Fly to Sir Abel Handy—Tell him to desist; order his people, on the peril of their lives, to leave the Castle instantly. Away.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir Philip Blandford, your conduct compels me to be serious.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Oh! forbear! forbear!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Excuse me, Sir,—an alliance, it seems, is intended between our families, founded on ambition and interest. I wish it, Sir, to be formed on a nobler basis, ingenuous friendship and mutual confidence. That confidence being withheld, I must here pause, for I should hesitate in calling that man father, who refuses me the name of friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Ah! how shall I act?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Is my demand unreasonable?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Strictly just—But, oh!—you know not what you ask—Do you not pity me?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Why then seek to change it into hate?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Confidence seldom generates hate— Mistrust always.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Most true.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I am not impelled by curiosity to ask your friendship. I scorn so mean a motive. Believe me, Sir, the folly and levity of my character proceed merely from the effervescence of my heart —you will find its substance, warm, steady, and sincere.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I believe it from my soul.—Allow me a moment's thought.— (Aside)—Suspicion is awakened, does not prudence as well as justice prompt me to confide in him. Does not my poverty command me. Perhaps, I may find a sympathizing friend—the task is dreadful—but it must be so—perhaps, he will perform the awful task of visiting the chamber, and removing every vestige of guilt. (To him) Yes, you shall hear my story, I will lay before your view the agony with which this wretched bosom is loaded.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I am proud of your confidence, and am prepared to receive it.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Not here—let me lead you to the eastern part of the Castle, my young friend—mark me: This is no common trust I repose in you; for I place my life in your hands.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: And the pledge I give for its security is what alone gives value to life, my honour.

div3.head: SCENE III.—A gloomy Gallery in the Castle—in the Centre a strongly barred Door.—The Gallery hung with Portraits.
div3.stage: HENRY discovered examining a particular Portrait, which occupies a conspicuous Situation in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Whenever curiosity has led me to this gallery, that portrait has attracted my attention— the features are peculiarly interesting. One of the House of Blandford—Blandford!—my name— perhaps my father. To remain longer ignorant of my birth, I feel impossible. There is a point when patience ceases to be virtue—Hush. I hear footsteps —Ah! Sir Philip, and another, in close conversation. Shall I avoid them?—No—Shall I conceal myself and observe them—Curse on the base suggestion!—No—

div3.stage: Enter Sir PHILIP and HANDY, jun.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: That chamber contains the mystery.

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Observe that portrait (seeing HENRY—starts). Who's there?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir, we wish to be private.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: My being here, Sir, was merely the effect of accident. I scorn intrusion (bows). But the important words are spoken—that chamber contains the mystery

sp.speaker: Handy, jun
sp.p: Who is that youth?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
You there behold his father—my brother— (weeps)—I've not beheld that face these
twenty years.—Let me again peruse its lineaments. (in an agony of grief) Oh, God! how I loved that man!—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Be composed.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I will endeavour. Now listen to my story.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You rivet my attention.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: While we were boys, my father died intestate, So I, as elder born, became the sole possessor of his fortune; but the moment the law gave me power, I divided, in equal portions, his large possessions, one of which I with joy presented to my brother.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: It was noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: At least it was just—we lived together, Sir, as one man; as my life I loved him, and selt no joys but what he shared—Sorrow I knew not.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Such love demanded a life of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: You shall now hear, Sir, how I was rewarded. Chance placed in my view a young woman of superior personal charms; my heart was captivated—Fortune she possessed not—but mine was ample. She blessed me by consenting to our union, and my brother approved my choice.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: How enviable your situation.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p:
Oh! (sighing deeply) On the evening previous to my intended marriage, with a mind serene as the departing sun, whose morning beam was to light me to happiness, I sauntered to a favourite tree, where, lover like, I had marked the name of my destined bride, and with every nerve braced to the tone of ecstacy, I was wounding the
bark with a deeper impression of the name—when, oh, God!—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Pray proceed!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: When the loved offspring of my mother, and the woman my soul adored—the only two beings on earth who had wound themselves round my heart, by every tie dear to the soul of man, placed themselves before me; I heard him— even now the sound is in my ears, and drives me to madness—I heard him breathe vows of love, which she answered with burning kisses—He pitied his poor brother, and told her he had prepared a vessel to bear her for ever from me.—They were about to depart, when the burning fever in my heart rushed upon my brain—Picture the young tiger, when first his savage nature rouses him to vengeance—the knife was in my gripe—I sprung upon them—with one hand I tore the faithless woman from his damned embrace, and with the other—stabbed my brother to the heart.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What followed?—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: At that dreadful moment my brother's servant appeared, and the vessel that was to wast him to happiness bore away his bleeding body; a few days brought the news that he had died suddenly in France, and all inquiry ceased
sp.stage: (exhausted he falls into HANDY, jun. arms).

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You are faint—But let me lead you from this place—Yet hold!—the wretched woman—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Was secretly conveyed here—even to that chamber.—She proved pregnant, and in giving birth to a son, paid the forfeit of her perjury by death.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Which son, is the youth that left us.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Even so—Tell me, could wretch be born possessed of a more solid title to my hate?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yet, he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My task being ended, yours begins.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Mine!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, that chamber contains evidence of my shame; the fatal instrument, with other guilty proofs, lie there concealed—can you wonder I dread to visit the scene of horror—can you wonder I implore you, in mercy, to save me from the task. Oh! my friend, enter the chamber, bury in endless night those instruments of blood, and I will kneel and worship you.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Will you (embraces him)? I am unused to kindness from man, and it affects me. Oh! can you press to your guiltless heart that blood-stained hand.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir Philip, let men without faults condemn; I must pity you.

div3.stage: Exeunt HANDY, jun. leading Sir PHILIP.

div2.trailer: THE END OF THE FOURTH ACT.

div3.head: SCENE I.—A wooded view of the country.
div3.stage: Enter SUSAN ASHFIELD, who looks about with anxiety, and then comes forward.

sp.speaker: SUSAN.
sp.p: I FEAR my conduct is very imprudent.—Has not Mr. Handy told me he is engaged to another? But 'tis hard for the heart to forego, without one struggle, its only hope of happiness; and conscious of my own honor, what have I to fear? Perhaps he may repent his unkindness to me—at least I'll put his passion to the proof; if he be worthy of my love, happiness is for ever mine; if not, I'll tear him from my breast, tho' from the wound my life's blood should follow. Ah, he comes—I feel I am a coward, and my poor alarmed heart trembles at its approaching trial—pardon me, female delicacy, if for a moment, I seem to pass thy sacred limits.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: By Heavens, the misfortunes of Sir Philip Blandford weigh so heavily on my spirits, that —but confusion to melancholy! I am come here to meet an angel, who will, in a moment, drive away the blue devils like mist before the sun. Let me again read the dear words; (reading a letter)I confess I love you still,(kisses the letter) but I dare not believe their truth till her sweet lips confirm it. Ah, she's there—Susan, my angel! a thousand thanks. A life of love can alone repay the joy your letter gave me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Do you not despise me?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; love you more than ever.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh, Robert, this is the very crisis of my fate.—From this moment we meet with honor, or we meet no more. If we must part, perhaps when you lead your happy bribe to church, you may stumble over your Susan's grave. Well, be it so.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Away with such sombre thoughts!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Tell me my doom—yet hold—you are wild, impetuous—you do not give your heart fair play—therefore promise me (perhaps 'tis the last favor I shall ask), that before you determine whether our love shall die or live with honour, you will remain here alone a few moments, and that you will give those moments to reflection.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I do—I will.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: With a throbbing heart I will wait at a little distance. May virtuous love and sacred honour direct his thoughts!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p:
Yes, I will reflect—that I am the most fortunate fellow in England. She loves me still—
what is the consequence? that love will triumph—that she will be mine—mine without the degradation of marriage—love, pride, all gratified—how I shall be envied, when I triumphantly pass the circles of sashion! one will cry, Who is that angel? another, "Happy fellow!" then Susan will smile around—will she smile? oh yes—she will be all gaiety—mingle with the votaries of pleasure, and—what! Susan Ashfield, the companion of licentious women! Damnation! no; I wrong her —she would not—she would rather shun society— she would be melancholy—melancholy, (sighs and looks at his watch) would the time were over. Pshaw! I think of it too seriously—'tis false—I do not—should her virtue yield to love, would not remorse affect her health? should I not behold that lovely form sicken and decay—perhaps die—die! then what am I? a villain—loaded with her parent's curses and my own. Let me fly from the dreadful thought—But how fly from it— (calmly) by placing before my imagination a picture of more honourable lineaments—I make her my wife. Ah! then she would smile on me—there's rapture in the thought —instead of vice producing decay, I behold virtue emblazening beauty—instead of Susan on the bed of death, I behold her giving to my hopes a dear pledge of our mutual love. She places it in my arms—down her father's honest face runs & tear, but 'tis the tear of joy. Oh, this will be luxury— paradise!—Come, Susan—come, my love, my soul, my wife!

div3.stage: Enter SUSAN—she at first hesitates—on hearing the word wife, she springs into his arms.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; those charms have conquered.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Oh! no; do not so disgrace the victory you have gained—'tis your own virtue that has triumphed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My Susan! how true it is, that fools alone are vicious. But let us fly to my father, and obtain his consent. On recollection, that may not be quite so easy. His arrangements with Sir Philip Blandford are—are—not mine, so there's an end of that. And Sir Philip, by missortune, knows how to appreciate happiness. Then poor Miss Blandford —upon my soul, I feel for her.

sp.speaker: Susan
sp.p: Come—don't make yourself miserable. If my suspicions be true, she'll not break her heart for your loss.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Nay, don't say so—she will be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: There he is. Dame, shall I shoot at un?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: My father's voice.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Then I'll leather un wi' my stick.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Zounds—no—come here.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: What do thee do here wi' my Sue, eh?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: With your Sue—she's mine—mine by a husband's right.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Husband! what, thee Sue's husband?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I soon shall be.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: But how tho'—? what, faith and troth, what, like as I married Dame?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: What, axed three times?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Yes; and from this moment I'll maintain that the real Temple of love is a parish church —cupid is a chubby curate, his torch is the sexton's lantern, and the according paean of the spheres is the profound nasal thorough bass of the clerk's Amen.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Huzza! only to think now—my blessing go with you, my children!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: And Heaven's blessing too. Ecod, I believe now, as thy feyther zays, thee canst do every thing.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; for there is one think I cannot do—injure the innocence of woman.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Drabbit it, I shall walk in the road all day to zee Sue ride by in her own coach.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You must ride with me, father.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: I say, Tummas, what will Mrs. Grundy say then?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: I do hope thee will not be asham'd of thy feyther in laa, woolye?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No; for then I must also be ashamed of myself, which I am resolved not to be again.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Heyday, Bob! why an't you gallanting your intended bride? but you are never where you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, by your own confession I am where I ought to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No; you ought to be at the Castle— Sir Philip is there, and Miss Blandford is there, and Lady Handy is there—and therefore—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: You are not there—in one word, I shall not marry Miss Blandford.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Indeed! who told you so?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: One who never lies—and therefore, one I am determined to make a friend of—my conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But, zounds, Sir, what excuse have you?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: A very fair one, Sir—is not she?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, yes, I can't deny it—but, 'sdeath Sir, this overturns my best plan.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No, Sir: for a parent's best plan is his son's happiness, and that it will establish. Come, give us your consent. Consider how we admire all your wonderful inventions.

sp.speaker: Sir Abe.
sp.p: No; not my plough, Bob—but 'tis a devilish clever plough.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I dare say it is. Come, Sir, consent and perhaps, in our turn, we may invent something that may please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: He! he! he! well—but hold—what's the use of my consent without my wife's—bless you! I dare no more say I approve, without—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Health to this worthy company.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: The same to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Who have we here, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I wish to speak with Sir Abel Handy.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: I am the person.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: You are married?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Damn it! he sees it in my face.—Yes, I have that happiness.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Is it a happiness?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: To say the truth—why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I want answers, not questions—and depend on't, 'tis your interest to answer me.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: An extraordinary fellow this!

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Would it break your heart to part with her?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir, that—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Answers—I want answers—would it break your heart, I ask?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Why, not absolutely I hope. Time, and philosophy, and—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I understand—what sum of money wou'd you give to the man who would dissolve your marriage contract?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: He means something, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Do you think so, Bob?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Would you give a thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: No; I would not give one; but I would give five thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Generously offered—a bargain—I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: But, an't you deceiving me?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: What should I gain by that?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Tell me your name?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Time will tell that.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Sir Abel—where are you▪

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: That's your wife's voice—I know it.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I'll wait without—Cry, "Hem!" when you want me.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Then you need not go far—
I dare not believe it—I should go out of my wits —and then if he fail, what a pickle I shall be in! Here she is.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: So, Sir, I have found you at last?

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My honoured mama, you have just come in time to give your consent to my marriage with my sweet Susan.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: And do you imagine I will agree to such degradation?

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Do'e, Lady Nelly, do'e be kind hearted to the young loviers—Remember how I used to let thee zit up all night a sweethearting.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Silence! and have you dared to consent?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, no, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Sir, you had better cry—"Hem!"

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I think it's time, Bob—Hem!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Hem!

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: What do you mean by—Hem?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Only, my dear, something troublesome, I want to get rid of—Hem!
There he is—never was so frightened in all my life.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: Gerald!

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady H.
sp.p: An't you dead, Gerald? Twenty years away and not dead?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: No, wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Wife! Did you say, wife?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Say it again.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She is my wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Once more.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: My lawful, wedded wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, my dear fellow!—Oh, my dear boy! Oh, my dear girl!— (embraces GERALD and the rest) Oh, my dear! (running to Mrs. GERALD) No—yes, now she an't my wife, I will— well—how will you have the five thousand? Will you have it in cash, or in bank notes—or stock, or India bonds, or lands, or patents, or—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: No—land will do—I wish to kill my own mutton.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Sir, you shall kill all the sheep in Hampshire.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Sir Abel, you have lost five thousand pounds, and with it, properly managed, an excellent wife, who, though I cannot condescend to take again as mine—you may depend on't shall never trouble you. Come! this way (beckoning to Mrs. GERALD)—important events now call on me, and prevent my staying longer with this good company. Sir Abel, we shall meet soon. Nay, come, you know I'm not used to trifle; come, come—
sp.stage: (she reluctantly, but obediently, crosses the stage, and runs off—GERALD follows).

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Come, come—That's a damn'd clever fellow! Joy, joy, my boy! Here, here, your hands—The first use I make of liberty, is to give happiness—I wish I had more imitators —Well, what will you do? (walks about exultingly.) Where will you go? I'll go anywhere you like—Will you go to Bath, or Brighton, or Petersburgh, or Jerusalem, or Seringapatam? all the same to me—we single fellows—we rove about —nobody cares about us—we care for nobody.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I must to the Castle, father.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Have with you, Bob (singing). "I'll sip every flower—I'll change every hour." — (beckoning)—Come, come—

div3.stage: Exeunt Sir ABEL, HANDY, jun. and SUSAN. SUSAN kisses her hand to ASHFIELD and DAME.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: Bless her! how nicely she do trip it away with the gentry!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And then, Tummas, think of the wedding.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: I declare I shall be just the zame as ever—may be I may buy a smartish bridle, or a zilver backy stopper, or the like o'that.

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: And, then, when we come out of church, Mrs. Grundy will be standing about there—

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: I shall shake hands agreeably wi' all my friends

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Then I just look at her in this manner.

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: How dost do, Peter—Ah, Dick —glad to zee thee wi' all my zoul
sp.stage: (bows towards the centre of the stage).

sp.speaker: Dame
sp.p: Then, with a kind of half curtesy, I shall—
sp.stage: (she advances to the centre also and their heads meet).

sp.speaker: Ash.
sp.p: What an wold fool thee bees't, Dame— Come along, and behave pratty, do'e.

div3.head: SCENE II.—The same as Act fourth, Scene third,
div3.stage: Enter HANDY, jun. with Caution, bearing a Light and a large Key.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Now to fulfil my promise with Sir Philip Blandford—by—entering that chamber, and removing—'Tis rather awful—I don't half like it, somehow, everything is so cursedly still. What's that? I thought I heard something—no—why, 'sdeath, I am not afraid—no—I'm quite su—su— sure of that—only every thing is so cursedly hush, and— (a flash of light and a tremendous explosion takes place) What the devil's that? (trembling) I swear I hear some one—lamenting—who's there?
Father!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel
sp.p: Bob!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Have you seen anything?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Oh, my dear boy!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Damn it, don't frighten one—

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Such an accident! Mercy on us!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I was mixing the ingredients of my grand substitute for gunpowder, when, somehow, it blew up, and set the curtains on fire, and—

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Curtains! zounds, the room's in a blaze.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Don't say so, Bob.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What's to be done? Where's your famous preparation for extinguishing flames?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It is not mixed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Where's your fire escape?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: It is not fixed.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Where's your patent fire-engine?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: 'Tis on the road.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Well, you are never at a loss.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: I don't know. I say, Bob, I have it —perhaps it will go out of itself!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Go out! it increases every minute —Let us run for assistance—Let us alarm the family.

sp.speaker: Sir Abel.
sp.p: Yes—dear me! dear me!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here, John! Thomas! some villain has set fire to the Castle. If you catch the rascal, throw him into the flames.

div3.stage: (Sir ABEL runs off and the alarm bell rings.)

div3.head: SCENE III.—The Garden of the Castle.—The effects of the Fire shewn on the Foliage and Scenery.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: The Castle in flames!—What occasioned it?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Alas, I know not!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Are the family in safety?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Sir Philip is.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: And his daughter?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Poor lady! I just now beheld her looking with agony from that window!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah! Emma in danger!—Farewell!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Are you mad? the great staircase is in flames.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: I care not! Should we meet no more, tell Sir Philip I died for his daughter!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Yet reflect.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Old man, do not cling to me thus— 'Sdeath! men will encounter peril to ruin a woman, and shall I hesitate when it is to save one?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Brave, generous boy! Heaven preserve thee!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Emma, my child, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: I fear, Sir, the Castle will be destroyed.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My child! my child! where is she! speak!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Alas! she remains in the Castle!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! then will I die with her!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Hold, dear master! if human power can preserve her, she is safe—The bravest, noblest of men has flown to her assistance.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Heaven reward him with its choicest blessings!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: 'Tis Henry.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Henry! Heaven will reward him— I will reward him!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: Then be happy! Look, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! dare I trust my eyes!

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: He bears her safe in his arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Bountiful Creator, accept my thanks!

div3.stage: Enter HENRY, bearing EMMA in his arms.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: There is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My child! my Emma, revive!

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Aye—now to unfold the mystery —The avenue to the eastern wing is still passable —the chamber not yet in flames—the present moment lost, and all is closed for ever. I will be satisfied, or perish.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Am I restored to my dear father's arms?

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Yes, only blessing of my life! In future thy wishes shall be mine—thy happiness my joy.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: My dear friend safe! and the lovely Emma in his arms! Then let the bonfire blaze.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: My young friend, do you mark? the flames will save the trial I imposed on you. Behold —they already burst from the eastern turret! Ere this they must have reached the chamber— that consumed, the secret is with us secure.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Oh, father, this unkind man has refused me, and given his hand to that sweet girl.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: I confess 'tis true—Your eyes can only fail to conquer those who are before subdued.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: But, Emma, where is your Henry? I wish to be just to him—I wish to thank him.

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: He has withdrawn to avoid our gratitude.—

sp.speaker: Everg.
sp.p: No—he again rushed into the Castle, exclaiming, I will penetrate that chamber, or perish in the attempt.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Then all is discovered.

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: Hush! for heaven's sake collect yourself!

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.p: Ah! (shrieks.) Thank heaven he's safe. What urged you, Henry, again to venture in the Castle?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Fate! the desperate attempt of a desperate man!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Yes; the mystery is developed. In vain the massy bars, cemented with their cankerous rust, opposed my entrance—in vain the heated suffocating damps enveloped me—in vain the hungry flames flashed their vengeance round me! What could oppose a man struggling to know his fate? I sorced the doors, a firebrand was my guide, and among many evidences of blood and guilt, I found —these!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: It is accomplished! Just heaven, I bend to thy decree!—Blood must be paid by blood! Henry, that knife, aimed by this fatal hand, murdered thy father!

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Miss B.
sp.stage: (placing herself between him and her father.)
sp.p: Henry! (he drops his hand.) Oh, believe him not! 'Twas madness! I've heard him talk thus wildly in his dreams! We are all friends! None will repeat his words—I am sure none will! My heart will break!—Oh, Henry! will you destroy my father?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Would I were in my grave!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah, Gerald here! How vain concealment! Well, come you to give evidence of my shame?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: I come to announce one, who for many years has watched each action of your life.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Morrington.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: I shall then behold the man who has so long avoided me—

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: But ever has been near you—he is here.

div3.stage: Enter MORRINGTON, wrapped up in his cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Well, behold your victim in his last stage of human wretchedness! Come you to insult me?
sp.stage: (MORRINGTON clasps his hands together and hides his face.)
sp.p: Ah! can even you pity me? Speak—still silent— still mysterious—Well, let me employ what remains of life in thinking of hereafter— (Addressing heaven) Oh, my brother! we soon shall meet again—And let me hope, that stript of those passions which make men devils, I may receive the heavenly balm of thy forgiveness, as I, from my inmost soul, do pardon thee.
sp.stage: (MORRINGTON becomes convulsed with agony, and falls into GERALD's arms.)
sp.p: Ah, what means that agony? He faints! give him air!—
sp.stage: (They throw open his cloak and hat.)
sp.p: (starts) Angels of mercy! my brother! 'tis he! he lives! Henry, support your father!

sp.speaker: Henry
sp.p: Ah, my father! he revives!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Hush!

div3.stage: (MORRINGTON recovers—seeing his brother, covers his face with shame, then falls at his feet).

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Crawling in the dust, behold a repentant wretch!—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: My brother, Morrington!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Turn not away—in mercy hear me!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: After the dreadful hour that parted us, agonized with remorse, I was about to punish home what your arm had left unaccomplished; when some angel whispered— Punishment is life, not death—Live and atone!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: On! go on!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I flew to you—I found you surrounded by sharpers—What was to be done? I became Morrington! littered with villains! practised the arts of devils! braved the assassin's steel! possessed myself of your large estates—lived hateful to myself, detested by mankind—to do what? to save an injured brother from destruction, and lay his fortunes at his feet!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Ah! is it possible?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, is that atonement? No—By me you first beheld her mother! 'Twas I that gave her fortune! Is that atonement? No—But my Henry has saved that angel's life—Kneel with me, my boy— lift up thy innocent hands with those of thy guilty father, and beg for mercy from that injured raint.

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: O, God! how infinite are thy mercies! Henry, forgive me—Emma, plead for me— There—there

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: But my father—

sp.speaker: Sir Philip
sp.p: Charles!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Philip!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: Brother, I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then let me die—blest, most blest!

sp.speaker: Sir Philip.
sp.p: No, no (striking his breast). Here —I want thee here—Raise him to my heart.
sp.stage: (They raise MORRINGTON—in the effort to embrace, be falls into their arms exhausted.)
sp.p: Again!

sp.speaker: Handy, jun.
sp.p: If forgiveness be an attribute which ennobles our nature, may we not hope to find pardon for our errors—here?

div1.head: EPILOGUE,
div1.byline: Written by MILES PETIT ANDREWS, Esq SPOKEN BY MR. FAWGETT.

lg.l: So here I am—once more to bear a bob,
And for our Author do a friendly job;
Perhaps you don't know how to clap a Play;
Mind me—hand rattle hand—thus (claps his hands)—that's the way!
No doubt you think, though second sure to none,
I'm rather sanguine about number One;
Ask all the world, who everything would try,
And all the world will answer, I! I! I!
Your sprightly Damsels seeking active fame,
Will rival schoolboys in each schoolboy game;
Give 'em but rope enough, they'll shine in skipping!
While many a lucky rogue may catch them tripping:
Others, with beauteous arm and lovely shoulder,
Conspicuous to each accurate beholder,
Vaulting on toe, with tamborine and bells,
Surpass the heroines of—Sadler's Wells!
Nor less our Beaux excite our admiration;
Their shoulders too are worthy observation;
Not bare indeed, but cas'd in tenfold stuffing—
They need not, if they like not, feel a cuffing;
Nay what's more frequent, and preserves as much,
They save the pressure of a Bailiff's touch.
Stuffing's a charm attracts us every minute;
E'en female bosoms find protection in it;
Expos'd to open charms and powerful flattery,
Why not gain conquests by a well-mask'd battery?
But truce to satire—Folly's lost in doubt,
And this age enters e'er that age goes out:
None know, so none to blame can find pretext,
Whether we sin last century or the next.
"You're a base man!" cries wealthy Madam Dump,
To her fond spouse who took her by the lump,
"To hide a wench last week behind the screen!"
"Last week, my love!—last Century you mean."
"Sure! says Miss Lydia Lank, an ancient maid,
"You will not countenance that painted jade:
"I hate to name the odious word miscarried;
"And yet the wanton minx was never married!"
"That's an old story!"—"Old! two months or so."
"Two months! you dream! a Century ago!"
"Dam'me!" cries Dash, "each age has its beginning!"
His chin quite buried in five rounds of linen;
"Think you we drive through life with too much haste?
"'Tis neck or nothing with us lads of taste!"
"Your taste!" cries Dad; "I fear your credit shocks,
"The rise of Cravats proves the fall of Stocks:
"Save then to-day, to-morrow we'll want some."
"To-morrow, Squaretoes! That's an Age to come!"
Since then from changeful Time's uncertain state,
Our very foibles now are out of date;
Let the Bard's faults find shelter on the Stage,
And let his labours live at least an age.
Chear with your smiles the Poet's growing joy—
A scanty harvest must his hopes destroy;
To brighten future prospects, all should now,
With heart and hand unite to—Speed the Plough!
